 Can any one add to the list?

Oh, I LOVED Maurice!!
 
 Here are a couple of others:
 
 La Mala Educacion (Bad Education)
 
 Lilies (an absolutely beautiful love story with a tragic ending. I highly recommend this).

Go Fish
 Love, Valore, Compassion
 Broken Hearts Club
 Bar Girls (omg, probably the lowest budget piece of lesbian trash!) 
 But I'm a Cheerleader (too dang funny!!!)
 Better Than Chocolate (gotta Love the "I'm Not A F#cking Drag Queen" number)
 Tripping The Velvet (quality BBC production starring Zoe Reynolds of MI-5 fame)
 Long time companion

 Bear Club 
 It's my Party
 Jeffrey (Too FUNNY...imagine Patrick Stewart[Star Trek Next Gen] as a flamboyant gay man!!!!)
 Relax, it's just sex (The "Friends" of the gay/lesbian world)
 Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil
 Trembling Before G_d (interesting documentary about Isreali Jewish Gays)
 A Matter of Taste (Un Affaire de Gout) [gotta not mind subtitles]
 Pricilla, Queen of the Desert
 Girls Will Be Girls (an ensable cast in the "But I'm a Cheerleader" and "Psycho Beach Party" group)
 Iron Ladies & Iron Ladies 2 (again, gotta not mind subtitles...hillariously funny ones from Thailand!)
 
 
 As we all know there are hundreds more, but these were just some that I recall having actually seen.

####ing Åmål (Show Me Love, 1998)
 
 Perhaps the best Swedish movie ever made. If you ever want to find out how it was to be a teenager in Sweden in the 90-ies (fat chance :p ), this is the movie you must see. The gay element in the movie is also brilliant and recflects the view of homosexuality among teenagers in Sweden at the time beutifly. I can`t recomend this movie enough, even though I suspect it might not be so rewarding to see it without being able to relate to the era and culture.
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/####ing_%C3%A5m%C3%A5l
 
 Tillsammans (Together, 2000)
 
 This is also a brilliant film made by Lucas Modyson and it has a few gay- and lesbian themes (even though this is never a central part of the movie). It`s about the Swedish 70-ies and portrays the problems of a collective household(?). When I saw it, I thought it was funny, but since I never quite experienced the 70-ies and the hippie movement, I couldn`t really relate. 
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tillsammans

Kiss Me Guido is a gay movie....not a romance though. A straight guy moves in with a gay guy for an apartment (he thinks "GWM" is "guy with money" haha) It's funny, like the Odd Couple. The straight one's like "oh no people will think I'm gay" and the gay guy's like "a straight guy? oh no. I'm gonna lose gay points!" or something...whatever, it's a funny movie...i lent it to a friend like 2 months ago and haven't seen it since

I thought Bound was excellent. Anyone else seen it?

 
 Unfortunately yes, personally I didn't care for it. At least not to be placed in the "Gay/Lesbian" movie bin. As a "good fellas" type, it was ok.
